The co-production of hydrogen and value-added biochemicals from lignocellulose utilizing solar energy has been regarded as one of the technologies most potentially able to alleviate the current energy crisis. Here, we demonstrate a cost-effective photoreforming strategy for lignocellulose valorization using a carbon nitride-supported platinum single-atom photocatalyst. An advanced H2 evolution rate of 6.34 mmol molPt –1 h–1 is achieved over the optimal catalyst, which is around 4.6 and 30.5 times higher compared with the nanosized Pt counterpart and pristine carbon nitride, respectively. Meanwhile, the monosaccharides are oxidized to value-added lactic acid with >99% conversion and extraordinary selectivity up to 97%. The theoretical calculations show that with Pt incorporation, the photogenerated holes are predominantly localized on the metal sites while the photogenerated electrons are concentrated on C3N4, thus enhancing the effective separation of charge carriers. This work provides a promising avenue for the simultaneous production of green H2 and bio-based chemicals by biomass photorefinery. Graphical Abstract PtSA-C3N4 enabled H₂ production over fourfold higher than Pt nanoparticles, efficiently converting sugars to lactic acid (~90%), offering a low-cost strategy for green hydrogen and biochemicals from lignocellulose. Keywords Carbon nitride Single-atom catalyst Lignocellulose photorefinery Hydrogen Biochemical 1 Introduction A booming trend in exploiting and utilizing new renewable energy (e.g., solar, wind, hydro, and bioenergy) has emerged to mitigate the over-consumption of petroleum-based fuels, thereby promoting the global zero-emissions economic transition [ 1–3 ]. Biomass reforming is a technology that can harvest and stock the earth-abundant biomass resources into green hydrogen possessing high gravimetric energy density, together with the coproduction of biogenic chemicals. It is thus regarded as an important bridge from low-market resources to high-value chemicals and fuels [ 4 ]. However, the conventional biomass-to-hydrogen technologies (e.g., gasification and pyrolysis) usually require harsh reaction conditions (e.g., high temperature and pressure) and large energy inputs, which also cause the formation of various by-products such as glycerol, formaldehyde, aniline, etc. [ 5–7 ]. In comparison, biomass photoreforming can be carried out exclusively under ambient conditions using inexhaustible solar energy as the sole input, inedible lignocellulose as feedstocks, and water as the solvent. Accordingly, this technology could contribute to achieving the carbon neutrality target with a higher grade of sustainability [ 8,9 ]. Yet, most of the previous studies used biomass resources as the sacrificial agents for photogenerated holes to accelerate charge-carriers separation and migration. Therein, the biomass resources were usually mineralized to CO2 or waste and caused extra environmental contamination [ 10,11 ]. Therefore, it is essential to develop efficient systems for photoreforming lignocellulose into H2 and high-value-added chemicals simultaneously. Although several successful examples have been developed for lignocellulose photoreforming in the past few years, including carbon dots (CDs) [ 12 ], carbon nitrides (C3N4) [ 13 ], and TiO2 [ 14 ], the unsatisfactory conversion and selectivity seriously hinder the processing of their downstream products and bring inferior economic feasibility [ 12,13,15,16 ]. Very recently, it has been demonstrated that monosaccharides (e.g., xylose and glucose) could be photoreformed into valuable lactic acid with high selectivity under alkaline conditions. However, the mechanism for the enhanced performance remained ambiguous and the preparation of the catalysts (e.g., Zn x Cd1–x S [ 17 ], CuO-chitosan hybrid hydrogel [ 18 ], Zn-doped C3N4 [ 19 ], etc.) was rather tedious or toxic. In addition, co-catalysts were always required to achieve satisfactory photoreforming efficiency. Therefore, the development of efficient dual-functional biorefinery systems is still in its infancy, and cost-effective photocatalysts are highly desired for advancing this field [ 20 ]. Among the explored library of photocatalysts, C3N4 emerges and has demonstrated a broad range of applications including hydrogen evolution, CO2 and N2 reduction, advanced oxidation process, organic synthesis, and lignocellulose photoreforming [ 21–28 ]. Since the seminal work of Zhang [ 29 ] in 2011, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted considerable interest and exhibited unique catalytic performance in various reactions due to the potential of 100% atom utilization and excellent selectivity. The efficient interaction between the supports and metals is the key to ensuring the atomic dispersion of the loaded metals both during the synthesis and the reaction [ 30 ]. In this regard, C3N4 is rich in nitrogen (ca. 60 wt%) which offers numerous uncoordinated sites for anchoring metal species and therefore has been extensively used as suitable support for different metal atoms [ 31,32 ]. Although the C3N4-based SACs have been successfully used in various reactions including thermocatalysis (e.g., hydrogenation [ 33 ], Suzuki coupling [ 34 ]), photocatalysis (e.g., hydrogen evolution [ 35,36 ], CO2 reduction [ 37 ], transfer hydrogenation [ 38 ], lignin depolymerization [ 39 ]), and electrocatalysis (e.g., CO2 reduction [ 40 ], H2O2 synthesis [ 41 ]), they are rarely used for lignocellulose photoreforming. Herein, we reported the photoreforming low-market-value lignocellulose into H2 and lactic acid under visible light and ambient conditions, using a C3N4-supported Pt-SAC (PtSA-C3N4). The optimal system exhibited a remarkable H2 evolution rate of 6.34 mmol molPt –1 h–1, which was 4.6-fold higher in comparison with its Pt nanoparticle counterpart (PtNP-C3N4) with similar loading (1.39 mmol molPt –1 h–1). It is worth mentioning that the monosaccharides (i.e., glucose, fructose, and xylose) could be efficiently oxidized to lactic acid with high conversion (>99%) and selectivity (up to 97%). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations demonstrated that the addition of single Pt atoms promotes the spatial separation of electron and hole, thus effectively prolonging the charge carrier lifetime. This study ingeniously integrates the production of green hydrogen and value-added biochemicals from lignocellulose by photorefinery. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and chemicals Melamine (MA, 99%, Aladdin), cyanuric acid (CA, 98%, Maclin), 4,4’-diamino-2,2’-bipyridyl (NH2-bpy, 97%, Macklin), chloroplatinic acid (Pt(NH3)4NO3, 50.0% Pt basis, Macklin), chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6, 98%, Macklin), glucose (98%, Macklin), fructose (99%, Macklin), cellulose (25 μm, Macklin), furfural (99%, Macklin), xylose (99%, Macklin), xylan (95%, Macklin) and guaiacol (>99%, Macklin), alkali lignin (L0082, TCI), sodium hydroxide (98%, Sinopharm), dimethyl sulfoxide (>99.8%, Macklin), isopropanol (IPA, 99.7%, Sinopharm), ammonium oxalate ((NH4)2C2O4, 98%, Macklin), potassium sulfate (K2S2O8, 99.5%, Macklin), and p-benzoquinone (BQ, 99%, Macklin). All chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Sample preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of g-C3N4 First, equimolar concentrations of melamine and cyanuric acid aqueous solution were mixed (v MA:v CA = 1:1) and stirred for 4 h to pre-form a supramolecular complex (CM). Then, the white precipitate was collected by centrifugation and dried at 358 K overnight. Finally, the g-C3N4 carrier was acquired after calcining the powder at 873 K (N2, 5 K min–1, 4 h). 2.2.2 Synthesis of PtSA-C3N4 To prepare 0.35 wt% PtSA-C3N4 was adopted the previous preparation method [ 42 ]: 100 mg g-C3N4, and 0.05 mL chloroplatinic acid (51.3 mmol L–1) were dispersed in 20 mL ultrapure water under sonication for 2 h and then stirred overnight at room temperature. Afterward, the water was removed by rotary evaporation at 333 K and dried in the oven overnight. Subsequently, the obtained powder was calcined at 573 K (N2, 5 K min–1, 5 h), and washed three times with NH4Cl (30 mL, 1 mol L–1) to remove the unloaded Pt precursor. Then, it was dried in an oven and finally calcined at 773 K (N2, 2 K min–1, 4 h to obtain PtSA-C3N4. The loading of Pt could be easily varied by using different amounts of chloroplatinic acid (51.3 mmol L–1) (0.5, 1.5, 2.5, 5.0, 7.5 mL for 0.10, 0.27, 0.35, 0.83, and 1.16 wt%, respectively). 2.2.3 Synthesis of PtNP-C3N4 Pt(NH3)4NO3 (0.83 mmol) and NH2-by (1.66 mmol) were dissolved in ultrapure water (20 cm3) and stirred at 353 K for 4 h to form a complex, then the resultant aqueous solution was added to melamine solution (8.34 mmol). After 30 min of stirring, the mixture was poured into cyanuric acid (10 mmol) to synthesize supramolecular precursor. Through vigorously stirring at 298 K for 4 h, the resulting solid was collected by centrifugation, and dried overnight at 333 K. Finally, the complex was calcined at 873 K (N2, 5 K min–1, 4 h), and the obtained powder was marked as PtNP-C3N4. 2.3 Characterization A Bruker D8 focal powder X-ray diffractometer fitted with Cu-Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA) was used to obtain wide-angle X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples at room temperature. The size distribution of Pt was analyzed by statistically examining over 50 particles. The average particle size was calculated using the formula: d Pt = ∑dn /n, where dn represents the size of each nanoparticle and n denotes the total number of Pt particle. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained on a Thermo ESCALAB 250XI with an aluminum anode (Al-K = 1486.6 eV). The metal loading of the samples was obtained by inductively coupled plasma photoemission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were measured on a VERTEX 80 V spectrometer after compression with KBr. Platinum metal or platinum dioxide was used as a reference sample. ATHENA software was used to analyze the data. Fitting results were obtained in k 3-weighted EXAFS oscillations using the ARTEMIS module. Ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS) were measured on a Lambda 950 spectrophotometer to evaluate the band gap (E g). A 5,5’-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) spin trap was added to the system, and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectral signals were collected with a Bruker A300 spectrometer after irradiation with a mercury lamp in the 9.843 GHz band. We dispersed 5 mg of catalyst and 50 μL of Nafion solution in 0.45 ml water, after sonication for 30 min of the above slurry, dropping 15 μL of it on a π × 0.6 × 0.6 cm2 FTO glass electrode and left it to dry naturally to obtain the working electrode. This experiment was performed with a lamp source of 40 W LED (427 nm) and 0.2 mol L–1 Na2SO4 aqueous solution as the electrolyte solution. In the process, different lignocellulosic substrates (100 mg), catalysts (10 mg), and aqueous NaOH solution (10 mol L–1, 5 cm3) were added to a 10 mL glass reactor. Prior to irradiation with a 40-W blue LED (427 nm), the reactor was blown with nitrogen for 5 minutes to remove residual air. The buildup of H2 was quantified by headspace analysis (1 mL) by gas chromatography (GC-2090) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and the use of ultra-pure argon as carrier gas. The valence-core interactions were described using the projector augmented-wave (PAW) method [ 51 ]. An energy cutoff of 400 eV was employed, and Brillouin zone integrations were performed with a 3×3×1 k-point mesh. The geometry optimizations were completed once the Hellmann-Feynman force on each relaxed ion was less than 0.05 eV Å–1. DFT calculations show that the monolayer C3N4 corrugated structure is the most stable, which is in agreement with previous findings [ 52–54 ]. To construct the cluster model of C3N4 (Fig. S13(b)), we first extracted a cluster composed of three linked heptazine rings that surround a six-fold cavity from the corresponding optimized periodic structure. Then, we capped the dangling bonds of the six terminal N atoms with nine H atoms. A similar procedure was used for the construction of the cluster model of PtSA-C3N4 (Fig. S14(b)). Calculations of the C3N4 and PtSA-C3N4 clusters were performed using Gaussian 16, employing the CAM-B3LYP functional [ 55 ] and def2-TZVP basis set [ 56 ]. During the ground-state geometry optimizations of the clusters, the six terminal N atoms were fixed while the other atoms were allowed to relax. Excited-state calculations on the clusters were performed by time-dependent density functional theory (TDDFT) with the adiabatic linear-response approximation [ 57 ]. To investigate the electronic transitions in the C3N4 and PtSA-C3N4 clusters, the first 100 excited states were calculated for each cluster. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and structure characterization Different Pt-supported C3N4 catalysts with distinct metal loading (i.e., 0.10 wt%, 0.27 wt%, 0.35 wt%, 0.83 wt%, and 1.16 wt%, quantified via inductively coupled plasma photoemission spectroscopy (ICP-OES)) and species (i.e., single atoms, clusters) were prepared according to an adapted two-step annealing approach under nitrogen atmosphere (Fig. 1(a) ), and the calcination temperature was determined based on thermogravimetric analysis (Fig. S1) [ 58 ]. Electron microscopy images indicate that the introduction of platinum did not alter the morphology of the catalyst (Fig. S2). The intrinsic structure was analyzed using FT-IR spectroscopy and XRD. As shown in Fig. S3, the heptazine ring peak at 809 cm–1 remains present, along with multiple characteristic peaks in the 1219–1618 cm–1 region corresponding to the stretching and bending vibrations of C–N conjugated heterocycles, as confirmed by FT-IR analysis [ 59 ]. Additionally, the XRD pattern exhibited no shift in the characteristic diffraction peak at 27.6°, corresponding to the (002) crystal plane, further confirming that the introduction of platinum did not alter the fundamental framework of the material [ 60 ]. Note that the platinum-related phases were not observed over PtSA-C3N4, implying the high dispersion of Pt throughout the C3N4 carrier. On the contrary, the peaks of metallic Pt (i.e., 39.8° (111) and 46.3° (220)) were identified on the nanoparticle-containing counterpart (PtNP-C3N4). The atomically dispersed Pt sites over PtSA-C3N4 were verified by aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF-STEM) images, showing sub-nanometer bright spots on the C3N4 carrier (Figs. 1(b) and S4). In contrast, a large number of Pt clusters (ca. 1.3 nm) and nanoparticles (ca. 4.2 nm) could be observed over PtC-C3N4 and PtNP-C3N4 (Fig. S5). Furthermore, the homogeneous distribution of C, N, and Pt throughout PtSA-C3N4 was confirmed by EDX images (Fig. 1(c)). The electronic structure characteristics of PtSA-C3N4 were analyzed by XPS, which exhibited a highly oxidized peak (Pt δ+, 0 < δ <2 at 73.0 eV of the Pt 4f 7/2 XPS spectrum (Fig. 1(d)). On the other hand, a significant contribution from metallic Pt0 (71.6 eV) was observed in the order of PtC-C3N4 and PtNP-C3N4 (Figs. 1(d) and S6), which highlighted the stronger interaction between Pt single atoms and C3N4 carrier PtSA-C3N4 [ 61,62 ]. Then, X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was applied to examine the coordination environment of Pt centers. As shown in Fig. 1(e), only a prominent peak at 1.62 Å assigning to Pt-N/C coordination was observed over the k 3-weighted Fourier transform EXAFS of PtSA-C3N4, without the presence of metallic Pt–Pt at 2.14 Å, which was indicative of the atomical dispersion of Pt throughout C3N4 support. The Pt-N/C coordination was further verified by the wavelet transform (WT) EXAFS analysis, which showed a maximum intensity of about 5.3 Å (Fig. 1(f)). Besides, the XANES of PtSA-C3N4 was recorded, showing a maximum white line intensity between PtO2 and Pt foil (Fig. 1(g)), indicating that the Pt atoms were in an oxidized state stemming from the Pt-N/C coordination, consistent with the result of XPS. According to the EXAFS fitting analysis (Figs. 1(h), (i) and Table S1), the coordination number of Pt-N/C was determined to be 3.2. 3.2 Photocatalytic hydrogen production performance Glucose photoreforming was applied as the model reaction to evaluate the catalytic performance of the developed PtSA-C3N4. The optimal amount of catalyst was found to be 10 mg with a maximum rate of hydrogen production of 4.33 mmol gcat –1 h–1, and further increasing the amount of photocatalyst was found detrimental probably due to the weakened light transmittance (Fig. 2(a) ) [ 63,64 ]. Meanwhile, the optimal amount of glucose was revealed to be 100 mg, while a higher concentration would lead to increased viscosity of the reaction solution which was unfavorable for the photoreforming (Fig. 2(b)) [ 65 ]. As shown in Fig. 2(c), there is a trace amount of hydrogen production in both acidic and neutral environments. A significant amount of H2 was generated only in a highly alkaline environment (pH > 13), indicating that the surface-adsorbed –OH ions could promote the generation of hydroxyl radical active species for glucose photooxidation [ 13 ]. The rate of hydrogen generation was found closely correlated with the metal content. As shown in Fig. 2(d), the catalytic activity increased significantly from 0.17 to 4.33 mmol gcat –1 h–1 when 0.35 wt% Pt was introduced, which tended to level off if further increasing the metal content to 1.16 wt% (5.14 mmol gcat –1 h–1). A comparison on a metal basis revealed a similar rate of hydrogen production when the content of Pt was below 0.35 wt% (6.34 mmol molPt –1 h–1, Fig. 2(e)), which suggested an equivalent available amount of active sites for glucose photoreforming in these catalysts. However, the catalytic efficiency of the Pt sites experienced an obvious decrease to 2.25 mmol molPt –1 h–1 when the Pt loading increased to 1.16 wt%, which was caused by the formation of clusters on carbon nitride, thus demonstrating the advantages of Pt single atoms for the reaction. Therefore, 0.35 wt% PtSA-C3N4 was selected as the optimal catalyst for the subsequent study by considering the catalytic performance both on a material and metal basis (simplified as PtSA-C3N4 without specific notifications). An additional Pt nanoparticle-containing reference counterpart (PtNP-C3N4) with similar metal content (0.35 wt%) to the optimized catalyst was prepared according to our previous work [ 21 ], which exhibited around 4.6 times lower efficiency of H2 production (1.39 mmol molPt –1 h–1), which further highlighted the excellent activity of the atomically dispersed actives sites over the conventional nanoparticles and clusters. The stability of the developed PtSA-C3N4 was confirmed by a consecutive cycling test, showing barely changed hydrogen production rate (Fig. S7). Post-analysis of the used catalyst by FT-IR, XRD, and HR-STEM demonstrated virtually identical structure and metal dispersion (Fig. S8). To identify the versatility of the system, different types of lignocelluloses (e.g., fructose, α-cellulose, furfural, xylose, xylan, guaiacol, and alkali lignin) were explored for photoreforming reactions (Fig. 2(f)). Among them, polysaccharides (i.e., α-cellulose, furfural, and xylan with H2 production rates of 1.50, 1.33, 0.89 mmol gcat –1 h–1, respectively) and lignin (guaiacol, lignin with H2 production rates of 0.70, 0.51 mmol gcat –1 h–1, respectively) showed lower rate of hydrogen generation compared to glucose (4.33 mmol gcat –1 h–1), fructose (4.1 mmol gcat –1 h–1), and xylose (3.3 mmol gcat –1 h–1), probably due to their higher spatial site resistance [ 66,67 ]. Concurrently, the liquid products from the photoreforming of glucose, fructose, and xylose were analyzed, achieving extraordinary yields of lactic acid (84.7%, 93.1%, and 96.5%, respectively (Fig. 2(g), and calibration curves in Fig. S9), which were among the best if compared to the previously reported systems (Table S2), suggesting the effectiveness of PtSA-C3N4 for the co-production of green H2 and bio-chemicals by lignocellulose photoreforming. Furthermore, control experiments without photocatalyst or light were conducted, which showed significantly lower yields for lactic acid, thus reinforcing the effectiveness of the prepared PtSA-C3N4 catalyst for lignocellulose photoreforming (Fig. S10). 3.3 Photocatalytic reforming of biomass reaction mechanism To gain insight into charge carrier separation and understand the source of the outstanding photocatalytic properties, a series of optical and photoelectrochemical measurements were performed. As shown in the UV-vis absorption spectra (Fig. S11), the incorporation of Pt single atoms led to a red shift in the absorption edge, indicating enhanced light absorption in the visible range. Additionally, PtSA-C3N4 exhibited the lowest PL intensity (Fig. 3(a) ), indicating that the incorporation of Pt single atoms significantly suppressed the recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs [ 67 ]. The LSV plot showed the highest H2 evolution current density over PtSA-C3N4 (Fig. 3(b)), suggesting the decreased activation energy and kinetic acceleration after anchoring atomic Pt sites [ 68 ]. Furthermore, the smallest arc radius was observed over PtSA-C3N4 in the EIS diagrams, indicating the lowest internal resistance for charge transfer (Fig. S12). Moreover, the transient photocurrent of PtSA-C3N4 was 3.2 and 1.7 times higher than that of C3N4 and PtNP-C3N4, respectively (Fig. 3(c)), which further demonstrated the enhanced charge transfer efficiency after atomic Pt incorporation [ 67 ]. A similar conclusion could be deduced from the solid-state EPR under light excitation (Fig. 3(d)). The uncoordinated electrons generated on the hybridized carbon atoms of the p 2 conjugated aromatic ring produce a single resonance peak at g¼ = 2.023, thus the superior EPR intensity of PtSA-C3N4 indicates maximum electron density over this sample [ 69,70 ]. All these results disclosed that the incorporation of isolated Pt atoms could effectively facilitate the transfer of the photogenerated charges and suppress their recombination, which explained the improved photoreforming activity of PtSA-C3N4 over PtNP-C3N4 and C3N4. To identify the radical species and enhance the elucidation of the reaction mechanism, ESR was employed using 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline (DMPO) as a spin-trapping agent. As shown in Fig. 3(e), no signal peaks were detected under dark conditions. Following a 10-minute exposure to light, strong quadruple signal peaks of DMPO/•OH with an intensity ratio of 1:2:2:1 and weak signal of DMPO/•O2 – with a ratio of 1:1:1:1 were observed, indicating that •OH and •O2 – radicals were generated upon light irradiation [ 18,71 ]. Afterward, trapping experiments were carried out to investigate the functions performed by these active species. As shown in Fig. 3(f), both the yield of lactic acid and rate of hydrogen production exhibited varied degrees of decrease after the addition of different scavengers (i.e., tert-butanol (TBA), ?OH scavenger; K2S2O8, e– scavenger; (NH4)2C2O4, h+ scavenger; p-benzoquinone (BQ), •O2 – scavenger), implying that these species all contributed to the glucose photoreforming process. In detail, the addition of TBA led to a marked suppression of lactic acid production, while having a negligible impact on H2 generation. The introduction of K2S2O8 resulted in a pronounced decline in H2 production, with the yield of lactic acid exhibiting a relatively modest decrease. These observations indicated that e– played a pivotal role in the reduction reaction, while ?OH radicals primarily drove the oxidation of glucose. Besides, the addition of (NH4)2C2O4 resulted in a reduction in both H2 and lactic acid, indicating that the reduction of h+ inhibited the progression of the reaction. Plus, it is noteworthy that the addition of p-benzoquinone (BQ) directly hindered the hydrogen production, probably due to the reaction between generated hydrogen and p-benzoquinone [ 72 ], which can be verified by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR, Fig. S13). Based on these results and existing reports, the reaction paths for photoreforming of monosaccharides were proposed (Fig. 3(g)). First, electrons and holes were generated under light conditions, which were transferred to the conduction band (CB) and valence band (VB) to reduce H+ to H2 and oxidize OH– to ?OH, respectively [ 73 ]. Meanwhile, glucose (GLU) and fructose (FRU) underwent isomerization in an alkaline environment, whose C–C bonds could be activated in the presence of ?OH species, triggering a retro-aldol reaction to form 1,3-di-hydroxyacetone (DHA). Lastly, lactic acid (LA) could be produced through the 1,2 H-shift of DHA intermediates. Specifically, these intermediates experienced dehydration to yield 2-hydroxypropenal (HYD), which further transformed to more stable pyruvaldehyde (PYA) through keto-enol, and then formed LA via rehydration [ 74 ]. Similarly, the cleavage of the C–C bonds in xylulose (XYLU), which derived from the isomerization of xylose (XYL), was initiated by hydroxyl radicals, resulting in the formation of DHA. Finally, lactic acid could be obtained through an analogous atomic rearrangement process [ 15 ]. Additionally, the details of the possible side reactions are provided in the supporting documentation (Figs. S14, and S15). 3.4 DFT calculations In order to gain insights into the improved photoactivity of the Pt-SAC system, DFT calculations were conducted on the C3N4 (Fig. S16) and PtSA-C3N4 clusters (Fig. S17). As displayed in Fig. S18, the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the C3N4 cluster were typically delocalized and spatially overlapped. In contrast, the HOMO of PtSA-C3N4 was predominantly localized on the Pt atom, while the LUMO was distributed over the C3N4 sheet (Fig. S19). Therefore, it could be expected that the photogenerated charge carriers can be more effectively separated on PtSA-C3N4 than on the bare C3N4. To confirm this, the excited-state calculations were then performed on the C3N4 and PtSA-C3N4 clusters. The results were summarized in Tables S3 and S4. The calculated UV-vis spectrum of the PtSA-C3N4 cluster (Fig. S20) was almost identical to the corresponding experimental spectrum, which confirmed the reliability of the computational methods for the current study. The electron-hole distributions of the first five excitations of the C3N4 and PtSA-C3N4 clusters were shown in Fig. 4 . Note that, the first 45 excitations all exhibited similar electron-hole distributions in each case. It was found that the excitations within the C3N4 cluster were localized, with the distributions of electrons and holes being spatially overlapped. In contrast, all five excitations exhibited Pt-to-C3N4 charge-transfer characteristics in the case of PtSA-C3N4, resulting in a spatial separation of charge carriers. Specifically, the hole was localized on Pt, while the electron was distributed over C3N4. The corresponding excitation energies and oscillator strengths were summarized in Table 1 . These findings were consistent with the experimental results, demonstrating that the incorporation of single Pt atoms could prolong the excited-state lifetime, thereby enhancing photocatalytic performance. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we reported the efficient co-production of value-added H2 and biochemicals from renewable lignocellulose resources (i.e., cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin) via photoreforming. The optimized PtSA-C3N4 exhibited an H2 evolution rate of 6.34 mmol molPt –1 h–1, which was 4.6 and 30.5-fold increase than that of PtNP-C3N4 and pristine carbon nitride under 427 nm light irradiation. Meanwhile, glucose, fructose, and xylose could be exclusively transformed into lactic acid with high yields of 84.7%, 93.1%, and 96.5%, respectively. Photoelectrochemical analysis and radical testing verified that the enhanced electron separation and migration ability on PtSA-C3N4 improved hydrogen production rates, while hydroxyl radicals generated by hole oxidation in an alkaline environment were crucial for efficient lactic acid production. Theoretical calculations indicated that the incorporation of single Pt atoms relocated the position of the HOMO to the Pt atom while retaining the LUMO over the C3N4 sheet, which promoted charge separation. This work provides a promising strategy for the sustainable production of hydrogen and bioproducts via the concept of a biomass photorefinery. coredata.dc:description: The co-production of hydrogen and value-added biochemicals from lignocellulose utilizing solar energy has been regarded as one of the technologies most potentially able to alleviate the current energy crisis. Here, we demonstrate a cost-effective photoreforming strategy for lignocellulose valorization using a carbon nitride-supported platinum single-atom photocatalyst. An advanced H2 evolution rate of 6.34 mmol molPt –1 h–1 is achieved over the optimal catalyst, which is around 4.6 and 30.5 times higher compared with the nanosized Pt counterpart and pristine carbon nitride, respectively. Meanwhile, the monosaccharides are oxidized to value-added lactic acid with >99% conversion and extraordinary selectivity up to 97%. The theoretical calculations show that with Pt incorporation, the photogenerated holes are predominantly localized on the metal sites while the photogenerated electrons are concentrated on C3N4, thus enhancing the effective separation of charge carriers. This work provides a promising avenue for the simultaneous production of green H2 and bio-based chemicals by biomass photorefinery.
